newsitem.title: USA: Clinton says tobacco deal must not cripple FDA.
newsitem.headline: Clinton says tobacco deal must not cripple FDA.

text.p: President Clinton on Friday said the tobacco settlement proposal was a "terrific achievement" but must not be allowed to paralyze the Food and Drug Administration.

"It was a terrific achievement," Clinton said of the negotiated settlement reached a week ago between the tobacco industry and state attorneys general. "But my preliminary take is that we do not want to paralyze the capacity of the FDA to protect the American people."
Under the accord, cigarette makers agreed to recognise the authority of the FDA to regulate tobacco and nicotine.
But critics, including leading U.S. public health groups, said the actual legal language in the accord would severely hamper FDA authority over tobacco. They demanded revisions.
Clinton's comments about the FDA appeared to be his most critical so far about the proposal, which a White House task force will study and which Congress would have to enact.

Clinton also lauded the pact as a historic achievement and said: "Even in Washington, $368 billion is a lot of money." Much of that money, to be paid by the tobacco industry under the accord, would go to public health and anti-smoking initiatives.
